Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that three private equity fund advisers within The Blackstone Group have agreed to pay nearly $39 million to settle charges that they failed to fully inform investors about benefits that the advisers obtained from accelerated monitoring fees and discounts on legal fees.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Hospital service provider TeamHealth Holdings, as successor in interest to IPC Healthcare Inc., f/k/a IPC The Hospitalists Inc., agreed to resolve allegations that IPC violated the False Claims Act by billing Medicare, Medicaid, the Defense Health Agency and the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program for higher and more expensive levels of medical service than were actually performed (a practice known as up-coding).
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/healthcare-service-provider-pay-60-million-settle-medicare-and-medicaid-false-claims-act
https://www.fra.dot.gov/eLib/details/L04899#p1_z5_gD_lEA

Description: Apria Healthcare LLC agreed to pay restitution and penalties in settlement of allegations it directly billed people for home healthcare products covered by the state's Medicaid program, in violation of Medicaid regulations and consumer protection laws.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20170916235558/http://www.mass.gov/ago/news-and-updates/press-releases/2017/2017-08-09-health-care-company.html

Description: Hotel chain Motel 6 agreed to pay $12 million to resolve the AG's privacy lawsuit against the company for voluntarily providing guest lists to agents of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) on a routine basis for over two years.
Info Source: https://www.atg.wa.gov/news/news-releases/ag-ferguson-motel-6-will-pay-12m-violating-privacy-tens-thousands-washingtonians

Description: Motel 6 agreed to contribute $750,000 to the Sacramento County District Attorney's Office of Public Safety and Community Improvement Trust Fund in a Memorandum of Understanding settling allegations its properties were failing to meet acceptable industry standards and practices, causing nuisances in the county.
Info Source: https://www.sacda.org/media/news-archives-2/2016-press-release-archives/3116-district-attorney-anne-marie-schubert-announces-joint-mou-motel-6/
https://web.archive.org/web/20090813022434/http://eeoc.gov/litigation/settlements/settlement03-05.html

Agency: Colorado Department of Public Health & Environment
Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on October 20, 2020 in response to an open records request.

Description: Vivint Smart Home Inc. agreed to pay the United States $3.2 million to resolve allegations under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 (FIRREA) that Vivint employees made false statements to secure financing for customers' purchases of Vivint's home monitoring products.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/vivint-smart-homes-inc-pay-32-million-resolve-allegations-false-statements-federally-insured

Company: Apria Healthcare Group, Inc. and Apria Healthcare LLC
Description: Apria Healthcare Group, Inc. and Apria Healthcare LLC agreed to pay $40 million to settle multistate allegations that it sought Medicaid reimbursement for ventilation machines that were not medically necessary or reasonable. The case also involved the U.S. Justice Department (see separate entry).
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-becerra-announces-40-million-nationwide-settlement-apria

Description: The lawsuit alleged, among other claims, that Apria submitted false claims to federal health programs, including Medicare and Medicaid, seeking reimbursement for the rental of costly non-invasive ventilators.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/acting-manhattan-us-attorney-announces-405-million-settlement-durable-medical-equipment

Description: Smart home security and monitoring company Vivint Smart Homes Inc. agreed to pay $20 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the Utah-based firm misused credit reports to help unqualified customers obtain financing for the company's products and services.
Info Source: https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2021/04/smart-home-monitoring-company-vivint-will-pay-20-million-settle
